name: Peanut Chutney
history: Peanut Chutney is a popular condiment in South Indian cuisine, particularly in Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. It's made from roasted peanuts and is known for its creamy texture and nutty flavor. This chutney is a common accompaniment to breakfast items like idli and dosa.
description: Peanut Chutney is a smooth and flavorful dip made from roasted peanuts, combined with spices, tamarind, and garlic. It's a versatile chutney that complements various South Indian dishes, adding a rich and nutty dimension to meals.

instructions.title: Roast Ingredients
instructions.description: Roast the peanuts in a pan until golden. Remove and set aside. In the same pan, roast the cumin seeds, mustard seeds, garlic, and green chilies for a few minutes.

instructions.title: Blend the Mixture
instructions.description: Combine the roasted peanuts, tamarind paste, the roasted spice mixture, salt, and a little water in a blender. Blend to a smooth consistency.

instructions.title: Prepare the Tempering
instructions.description: Heat oil in the pan. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves. When they start to splutter, remove from heat.

instructions.title: Combine and Serve
instructions.description: Pour the tempering over the blended peanut mixture. Serve the Peanut Chutney with idli, dosa, or other South Indian dishes.

tips: Adjust the amount of green chilies based on your spice preference.
Ensure the peanuts are well-roasted for the best flavor.
variations: Add a small piece of jaggery for a hint of sweetness.
Include a handful of fresh coriander leaves for a refreshing twist.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Peanut Chutney is best served at room temperature and does not require reheating.

presentationTips: Serve in a small bowl with a spoon for easy use.
Garnish with a few roasted peanuts on top for added texture.
